title: Quotation of the Day: Risky New Phase Brings Discord and Unease
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 2, 2020.
content: “It is like having a smoking section on a plane or in a restaurant. It doesn’t work.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 41 Classic Dishes You Should Master
description: Simplest roast chicken, chocolate chip cookies and more recipes.
content: It might be time to brush up on some of the basics: Mark Bittman’s simplest roast chicken, Alison Roman’s eggs Benedict (above), Julia Moskin’s classic French toast and more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Joe Says It Ain’t So
description: With partisan goggles, we plunge back into the muck.
content: WASHINGTON — One of my quarantine diversions was revisiting the first season of “Mad Men,” where women in the workplace were sexual playthings and where a young woman’s assay at writing ad copy was so unorthodox that it was, as one ad man marveled, like watching a dog play the piano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett McGurk
title: The Father I Never Forgave
description: He left my life when I needed him most. And then he came back.
content: In the summer of 1980, I was 7 years old and crazy about the Pittsburgh Pirates. The team had won the World Series the year before, and because the Steelers won the Super Bowl in 1979 and 1980, people started calling the place “City of Champions.” To a kid, this was the center of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: A Young Doctor, Fighting for His Life
description: “I just went down on my knees,” his mother recalled later. “I just implored God for mercy.”
content: Dr. Andres Maldonado normally bounded into the Emergency Department, fit and vigorous, but this time he had to be escorted in, pale and fighting for breath, with a patient bracelet on his right wrist. A nurse, seeing her colleague struggle, burst into tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: New York Is Wounded. I Miss It More Than Ever.
description: A former city reporter went to the Middle East, looking for the big story. Now she yearns for the city she thought she was happy to leave behind.
content: I live in Beirut, Lebanon, but in this season of confinement I could be anywhere. I have left my apartment eight times in six weeks; my brushes with the city where I’ve lived for a year and a half are so brief, I forgot that I lived near the sea until I went up on a roof and my eyes confronted the blue fact of the Mediterranean. In my apartment, with friends nine time zones away as accessible as friends down the block, I Zoom far and wide. I could be anywhere, but some part of me wants to be in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Jones and Miya Lee
title: What Does Modern Love Mean in a Pandemic?
description: At first we thought the column could be a break from the coronavirus. A flood of submissions told us that wasn’t possible.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Stewart and Nate Schweber
title: Stark Symbol of Pandemic in N.Y.: Homeless People Huddled on the Subway
description: New Yorkers with no better place to go keep riding and sleeping on otherwise empty trains, stirring public health fears and prompting a nightly shutdown for cleaning.
content: Every No. 2 train that lumbered into the last stop in the Bronx late Wednesday night had, at most, a couple of dozen passengers. And when the doors swooshed open, half of them had no intention of getting off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Fearing Political Peril, Republicans Edge Away From Trump on Pandemic Response
description: Moderate Republicans in competitive districts are navigating a careful balance in addressing the coronavirus crisis, eager to put some distance between themselves and a president whose response has been criticized.
content: WASHINGTON — Every evening from his kitchen table in southwestern Michigan, Representative Fred Upton, a moderate Republican running for his 18th term in office, posts a coronavirus dispatch for his constituents, highlighting his own efforts to respond to the crisis and the news from Washington, often with cameos from Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Go Ahead, Blow Out the Candles on Zoom
description: You or your loved one is another year older no matter what, so why not celebrate?
content: In a strange twist, a pandemic birthday party might actually be the easiest party you ever throw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Fearing Political Peril, Republicans Edge Away From Trump on Pandemic Response
description: Moderate Republicans in competitive districts are navigating a careful balance in addressing the coronavirus crisis, eager to put some distance between themselves and a president whose response has been criticized.
content: WASHINGTON — Every evening from his kitchen table in southwestern Michigan, Representative Fred Upton, a moderate Republican running for his 18th term in office, posts a coronavirus dispatch for his constituents, highlighting his own efforts to respond to the crisis and the news from Washington, often with cameos from Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Relaxed Rules and Warm Weather Test States
description: Congress declined the administration’s offer of rapid testing, saying tests were needed more elsewhere. Former President George W. Bush urged unity in a video message.
content: Warmer weekend temperatures and fatigue over weeks of confinement lured millions of Americans outside on Saturday, adding to the pressure on city and state officials to enforce, or loosen, restrictions imposed to limit the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un Is Back. What Happens When He’s Really Gone?
description: Weeks of speculation about Mr. Kim’s health brought home an alarming fact: No one knows who will control North Korea, or its nuclear weapons, should he die.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, reappeared in dramatic fashion this weekend when he was shown on North Korean media after three weeks of unexplained absence, cutting the ribbon on a fertilizer factory — and quieting rumors that he was gravely ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, David D. Kirkpatrick, Carl Zimmer, Katie Thomas and Sui-Lee Wee
title: Profits and Pride at Stake, the Race for a Vaccine Intensifies
description: Governments, companies and academic labs are accelerating their efforts amid geopolitical crosscurrents, questions about safety and the challenges of producing enough doses for billions of people.
content: WASHINGTON — Four months after a mysterious new virus began its deadly march around the globe, the search for a vaccine has taken on an intensity never before seen in medical research, with huge implications for public health, the world economy and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Filmmaker Who Mocked Egypt’s President Dies in Prison
description: Shady Habash had been held without trial at a maximum-security prison for two years. His lawyer said the cause of death was unknown.
content: CAIRO — An Egyptian filmmaker imprisoned over a music video that mocked President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi died at a maximum-security facility on Friday after two years in detention without trial, his lawyer said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 41 Classic Dishes You Should Master
description: Simplest roast chicken, chocolate chip cookies and more recipes.
content: It might be time to brush up on some of the basics: Mark Bittman’s simplest roast chicken, Alison Roman’s eggs Benedict (above), Julia Moskin’s classic French toast and more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Su-Hyun Lee
title: No More Jenga, No More ‘Amen’ as Cities Learn to Live With Coronavirus
description: In parts of Asia and Australia, people are going out — but social distancing and other restrictions have become the new normal.
content: Worshipers at one of Seoul’s largest Catholic churches must refrain from singing hymns or saying “amen” for fear of spreading saliva. Priests sanitize their hands during communion. Holy water has been removed from the chapel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Jewish Characters Star in Saudi TV Show, Igniting an Arab Debate
description: Fans have praised a hit TV series for promoting religious diversity. Critics say it encourages “normalization” with Israel and betrays the Palestinian cause.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a mud-walled village in the Persian Gulf, a Christian woman sheds tears of love for a Muslim merchant. But he is stuck in a miserable marriage to a woman who longs for another Muslim man. But she can’t have him, because he is crazy about the local rabbi’s daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Players Union Will Review Disability Benefits
description: Under the collective bargaining agreement ratified in March, more than 400 retired players are set to see reductions to their monthly benefits.
content: The N.F.L. Players Association announced plans to review provisions in the collective bargaining agreement ratified in March that are set to take away tens of thousands of dollars in benefits from permanently disabled former players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Votes, Deployment and Now Parenthood in the Middle of a Pandemic
description: Representative Max Rose of New York and his wife welcomed a son and are now juggling parenthood and Congress during the age of coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers gathered in the well of the House in the early hours of March 14 to vote on a sweeping coronavirus relief bill, Representative Max Rose, Democrat of New York, felt that the pandemic that had already begun spreading through the ranks of Congress was about to upend life as he knew it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Can U.S. Soccer and Its Women’s Team Make Peace on Equal Pay?
description: A federal judge’s rejection of the players’ equal pay claims cost the team their leverage, but it is in the federation’s interests to find a settlement both sides can embrace.
content: After a federal judge dismissed the equal pay claims of the World Cup-winning women’s national team on Friday night, it was not the words in the United States Soccer Federation’s response that stuck out. It was the ones that weren’t there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Married Doctors Learn to Meet in the Middle
description: Monique Collier Nickles and Leroy Nickles, physicians on the front line of the coronavirus pandemic, share why it’s more important than ever to have frequent relationship check-ins.
content: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Stockton and Nicholas Kristof
title: A 27-Year-Old Doctor’s Fight Against Coronavirus
description: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.
content: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Antarctica vs. Science
description: For researchers using delicate, one-of-a-kind equipment, the extreme conditions at the bottom of the planet pose special challenges.
content: At the start of January, the same month the world marked the 200th anniversary of the discovery of Antarctica, scientists on snowmobiles were zipping across its diamantine ice, dragging a rig of metal detectors in their wake. Researchers were hoping to discover a hypothesized cache of iron-rich meteorites, the remnants of ancient asteroids and would-be planets, under the frozen wastes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Photos of Life Transformed by a Pandemic
description: People are seeking a bit of normalcy as governments wrestle with the shutdowns aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus.
content: Restaurants received patrons into dining rooms that were partially cordoned off for social distancing, friends sought safe conversation in the sunshine and some people tried to continue a productive path forward in isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: Track Where Your Money Goes
description: First step, actually open up those bank and credit card statements.
content: Where does your money go each month? Now, especially, with financial goals and priorities in flux, it’s important to know in granular detail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George McGraw
title: How Do You Fight the Coronavirus Without Running Water?
description: Entire communities around the country face this terrifying virus without being even able to wash their hands.
content: Several weeks ago, Larry Welch and his mother, Mary Ann, contracted Covid-19 and died. In the midst of a pandemic in which one of the first lines of defense is vigorous hand washing, they were among more than two million Americans who lack running water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Cade Metz
title: ‘I Could Solve Most of Your Problems’: Eric Schmidt’s Pentagon Offensive
description: The former Google C.E.O. has reinvented himself as the prime liaison between Silicon Valley and the military-industrial complex.
content: In July 2016, Raymond Thomas, a four-star general and head of the U.S. Special Operations Command, hosted a guest: Eric Schmidt, the chairman of Google.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: 9/11 Prisoners May Get Video Chats to Bridge the Coronavirus Divide
description: With the Sept. 11 hearings delayed, prosecutors and defenders are looking for ways to let lawyers talk with the prisoners at Guantánamo Bay.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Kevin Draper
title: Can Golden Boy Bring Boxing Back?
description: Oscar De La Hoya has a hope — live boxing on July 4, probably with no fans, but a 10-card event to get the sport back. The fighters he promotes are training in garages and living rooms.
content: Oscar De La Hoya, the boxing champion turned promoter, spends a part of each day running up and down his half-mile long driveway in Pasadena, Calif., to stay in shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Stockton and Nicholas Kristof
title: A 27-Year-Old Doctor’s Fight Against Coronavirus
description: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.
content: Dr. Andres Maldonado was on the front lines treating patients. Then he got sick too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Votes, Deployment and Now Parenthood in the Middle of a Pandemic
description: Representative Max Rose of New York and his wife welcomed a son and are now juggling parenthood and Congress during the age of coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers gathered in the well of the House in the early hours of March 14 to vote on a sweeping coronavirus relief bill, Representative Max Rose, Democrat of New York, felt that the pandemic that had already begun spreading through the ranks of Congress was about to upend life as he knew it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Can U.S. Soccer and Its Women’s Team Make Peace on Equal Pay?
description: A federal judge’s rejection of the players’ equal pay claims cost the team their leverage, but it is in the federation’s interests to find a settlement both sides can embrace.
content: After a federal judge dismissed the equal pay claims of the World Cup-winning women’s national team on Friday night, it was not the words in the United States Soccer Federation’s response that stuck out. It was the ones that weren’t there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: ‘Murder Hornets’ in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet
description: Sightings of the Asian giant hornet have prompted fears that the vicious insect could establish itself in the United States and devastate bee populations.
content: BLAINE, Wash. — In his decades of beekeeping, Ted McFall had never seen anything like it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Judge Vacates Oil and Gas Leases on 145,000 Acres in Montana
description: A federal judge, rapping the Trump administration for its weak environmental assessments, has vacated hundreds of oil and gas leases across a large swath of Montana.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday vacated 287 oil and gas leases on almost 150,000 acres of land in Montana, ruling that the Trump administration had improperly issued the leases to energy companies in 2017 and 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Put Your Children to Work
description: Also: why some parents are giving their kids CBD.
content: As noted earlier this week, I do not enjoy generating fun for my children. So I was very pleased to read our piece from Michaeleen Doucleff, an NPR correspondent who has spent years reporting on how different cultures around the world raise cooperative and generous children. “In these cultures, you find a striking commonality: Mothers and fathers do not feel the need to constantly entertain and play with children,” Michaeleen wrote. “Instead parents give children an opportunity that many American kids do not have — to participate in adult work.” How do we get our American children to behave this way? She has suggestions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Standing on a Step Stool to Kiss the Groom
description: A 5 foot 4 lawyer and a 6 foot 5 physicist were first taken by each other’s smile.
content: Martin Schmaltz, a physics professor at Boston University, preferred to study the rate of the expansion of the universe over dating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Victor J. Blue
title: A Family Rallied on 2 Continents as a Loved One Fought Covid-19
description: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.
content: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Daniel Rayman’s cryptic puzzle dances into Sunday.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — For the record, I declared 2020 the Year of the Cryptic Crossword well before we got quarantined, and now there are still more reasons to show them some love.   Many of us find that our lives are moving at a slower pace, perfect for mulling and letting the problem-solving part of our brain get a chance to work with less commotion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Deaths in New York Increase Slightly, Cuomo Says
description: Balmy weather in the New York area brought flocks of people to parks, presenting a challenge for efforts to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo arrived on Saturday to the New York City Transit’s Corona Maintenance Facility in Queens to deliver a sliver of bad news in the fight against the coronavirus: The state’s daily death toll went up slightly after a consistent decline in the past few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: The 450-Plus Guest List Will Have to Wait
description: Ayana Coston and Clinton Jordan Jr. were forced to significantly scale down their wedding plans, but still hope to eventually have a big reception.
content: Ayana Coston and Clinton Jordan Jr., friends for 17 years who began dating about 18 months ago, had set a wedding date for May 23 with a guest list that kept growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Victor J. Blue
title: A Family Rallied on 2 Continents as a Loved One Fought Covid-19
description: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.
content: Family members gathered on conference calls to send her messages of courage, and prayed together for a miracle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Did Closing Schools Actually Help?
description: Researchers have a plan to find out.
content: As different countries and states tentatively start reopening their economies, there seems to be no clear plan, and no clear way to figure out which of the lockdown measures made a difference in slowing the spread of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Standing on a Step Stool to Kiss the Groom
description: A 5 foot 4 lawyer and a 6 foot 5 physicist were first taken by each other’s smile.
content: Martin Schmaltz, a physics professor at Boston University, preferred to study the rate of the expansion of the universe over dating.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kansas Primary Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results from the Kansas presidential primary election.
content: Detailed results from the Kansas presidential primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Deaths in New York Increase Slightly, Cuomo Says
description: Balmy weather in the New York area brought flocks of people to parks, presenting a challenge for efforts to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo arrived on Saturday to the New York City Transit’s Corona Maintenance Facility in Queens to deliver a sliver of bad news in the fight against the coronavirus: The state’s daily death toll went up slightly after a consistent decline in the past few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Hamilton Bohannon, Driving Disco Drummer, Dies at 78
description: Mr. Bohannon’s steady four-on-the-floor beat kept dancers moving, and many of his tracks became hip-hop samples long after disco’s heyday.
content: Hamilton Bohannon, a drummer whose disco records propelled people onto dance floors in the 1970s and ’80s, and then lived on as popular samples for major hip-hop artists, died on April 24 at his home in Atlanta. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: Was That a Cough? Going Back to the Movies in Texas
description: A few movie theaters in Texas opened on Saturday, early experiments in back-to-normal living after a long coronavirus lockdown.
content: SAN ANTONIO — It happened early inside the cool, darkened cineplex, before Vin Diesel even had a chance to turn superhuman, as people sat munching popcorn and sipping sodas in their plush recliner seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Colorado Paramedic Who Came to Help New York Dies From Covid-19
description: For three weeks, Paul Cary transported coronavirus patients to hospitals by ambulance. He had already signed up for a second 30-day deployment in New York when he started feeling sick.
content: On the same day that New York City’s 911 dispatchers fielded a volume of calls not seen since the Sept. 11 attacks, Paul Cary, a paramedic, set out for the nearly 1,800-mile drive from Denver to New York City in an ambulance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Daniel Rayman’s cryptic puzzle dances into Sunday.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — For the record, I declared 2020 the Year of the Cryptic Crossword well before we got quarantined, and now there are still more reasons to show them some love.   Many of us find that our lives are moving at a slower pace, perfect for mulling and letting the problem-solving part of our brain get a chance to work with less commotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Seeing an Old Friend With New Eyes
description: Ebba Palmstierna and Bennett Eastham first met in 2008 when she was a foreign exchange student living on his family’s farm.
content: When Bennett Eastham needed a mental-health break last June from working long hours at a Virginia law firm, he made plans to travel to Copenhagen to see Andrew Bird, an American singer, perform there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Let’s (Not) Shake on It
description: The simple handshake, once an offer of peace, now carries a threat of contagion.
content: Handshaking for self-protection became anachronistic long before Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious-disease expert, said wistfully in early April that as far as even greeting one another, “we may never shake hands again.” As a personal defense mechanism and for sealing deals, though, it was outdated as soon as people began openly brandishing guns and hiring lawyers to vet contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zio Baritaux
title: 10 Florists Delivering Vibrant Bouquets for Mother’s Day
description: During this time of self-isolation, when the floral industry, too, is hurting, a colorful missive feels more meaningful than ever.
content: Sending flowers on Mother’s Day has long been a way to convey closeness despite physical distance. Now, with many people self-isolating away from their families, this small act feels especially poignant. But as businesses have closed on account of the coronavirus, and as events have been postponed or canceled, the demand for flowers has withered and growers have been forced to destroy millions of blooms. “Flowers are a very low-margin, high-labor, perishable medium, and our supply chains are complex and vulnerable,” explains the Manhattan-based floral designer Emily Thompson, who hopes to reopen soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The New Great Depression Is Coming. Will There Be a New New Deal?
description: After the coronavirus, political transformation may be inevitable.
content: Until very recently, Andrew Yang thought that the need for a universal basic income would be a big issue in the 2024 election, as “many of the trends that I campaigned on were going to become completely clear to more and more Americans” over the next four years. He was arguing, for example, that between now and then, “30 percent of our stores and malls were going to close because of Amazon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Poker-Faced
description: Paolo Pasco’s Saturday puzzle protects its mysteries.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really cool-looking and inviting grid from Paolo Pasco; it might be a slightly sloppy smiley face, or a postmodern dollar sign. The actual solve is hard to break into, but the middle portion winds up being pretty doable. The stepping stacks at the top and bottom are almost all debuts, including a bit of lingo, so you need a good ear for catchphrases and a little luck to finish.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 2, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 2, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about the overnight closing of New York’s subway referred imprecisely to the city’s public transit schedule. It is the only system in the United States that runs all of its train lines 24 hours a day; it is not the only system in the country to operate 24 hours a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Warner
title: The War Between Middle Schoolers and Their Parents Ends Now
description: The coronavirus lockdown is an opportunity for a reset.
content: Millions of American parents are now stuck at home with their middle schoolers and becoming intimately reacquainted, in far too close quarters, with the look, smell and feel of life — 24/7 — in the sixth, seventh and eighth grades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Shifting Sounds
description: Ben Zimmer makes his crossword debut, with Brendan Emmett Quigley, and it’s no stroll in the park!
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is probably a celebrity puzzle for a lot of word lovers out there; Ben Zimmer is a prolific writer on language, formerly at the Times, currently at The Wall Street Journal and The Atlantic. According to Will Shortz’s print introduction, Mr. Zimmer and Brendan Emmett Quigley met about 12 years ago while working on the Visual Thesaurus. (Mr. Zimmer had a column there as well, “Word Routes,” which we have cited before in Wordplay.) This grid is a collaboration from start to finish, a fusion of two maven brains on a molecular level, if you will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Asadullah Timory
title: Afghanistan Investigating Claims Migrants Were Killed by Iranian Guards
description: About 50 Afghan migrants crossing into Iran illegally were beaten and thrown into a river, local news media and witnesses say. As many as half did not survive, they said.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The foreign ministry of Afghanistan on Saturday said it was investigating claims that dozens of Afghan migrants detained in Iran were tortured by that country’s border guards and thrown into a river, where many of them drowned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Tony Allen, Drummer Who Created the Beat of Afrobeat, Dies at 79
description: With the Nigerian bandleader Fela and later on his own, he merged West African styles with American jazz and funk, reaching listeners worldwide.
content: Tony Allen, the drummer who created the steadfast, subtle beat of the Nigerian protest funk known as Afrobeat, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Matt Phillips
title: Berkshire Hathaway Lost $49.7 Billion in First Quarter Stung by Coronavirus
description: The huge loss reflects the hit that the crisis has inflicted on Warren E. Buffett’s vast conglomerate.
content: Not even Warren E. Buffett was spared financially from the coronavirus, as his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, reported a $49.7 billion loss in the first quarter on Saturday, reflecting the outbreak’s toll on an investment portfolio that includes big stakes in major airlines and financial firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: With Over Two Dozen Deaths, London Bus Drivers Fear Coronavirus Risk
description: At least 28 bus drivers have died since the coronavirus outbreak began. And while new measures have been put in place to protect them, some worry it’s too little, too late.
content: London is a city gone quiet. Yet, with a stringent coronavirus lockdown in place and the normal bustle largely halted, bold red buses are still winding their way through the sprawling capital offering frequent service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley, Emily Flitter and David Enrich
title: Some Small Businesses That Got Aid Fear the Rules Too Much to Spend It
description: Requirements for using federal coronavirus loans are complicated and confusing for owners. “It’s chaos,” one lawyer said.
content: When a $192,000 loan from the federal government’s small-business aid program arrived in his bank account last month, George Evageliou, the founder of a custom woodworking company, felt like one of the lucky ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: With No Kentucky Derby, Live and Virtual Substitutes Emerge
description: The Kentucky Derby was originally scheduled for Saturday. An animated race airing on NBC may be the most prominent replacement, even though horses will race elsewhere in the country.
content: There will be a derby on Saturday. Three of them, in fact. Churchill Downs is hosting a virtual Kentucky Derby, one pitting all 13 Triple Crown winners against one another in a simulated race, while Oaklawn Park will run the Arkansas Derby. Twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Houston Helicopter Crash Kills 1 Police Officer and Injures Another
description: The officers were investigating a report of bodies in a bayou when the helicopter crashed near an apartment building, the authorities said.
content: A Houston police officer was killed and another critically injured after their helicopter crashed early Saturday morning as they were responding to a report of bodies in a bayou, the city’s police chief said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden and the Presumption of Innocence
description: Being heard is not, and should never be, the same thing as being believed.
content: Regarding Tara Reade’s allegation that she was sexually assaulted by Joe Biden in 1993, and what the allegation could mean for Democrats this fall, some stock phrases come to mind. Hoisted on their own petard. What’s sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander. Be careful what you wish for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Investigate Tara Reade’s Allegations
description: Americans deserve to know more about a sexual assault accusation against the likely Democratic Party nominee.
content: Former Vice President Joe Biden, the Democrats’ presumptive nominee for president, has forcefully denied allegations of sexual harassment and assault made against him by Tara Reade, a former staff assistant in his Senate office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: She Predicted the Coronavirus. What Does She Foresee Next?
description: Laurie Garrett, the prophet of this pandemic, expects years of death and “collective rage.”
content: I told Laurie Garrett that she might as well change her name to Cassandra. Everyone is calling her that anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Play This: The Paperback Game
description: All you need is some pulp fiction and a good imagination.
content: My family didn’t invent the paperback game (I don’t know who did), but we’ve played it for years. It’s for four to 10 people and perfect for lockdown. You can play at the table after dinner, after the dishes have been cleared and everyone is loosened up. An Earl Hines record on in the background sets the mood perfectly. Here’s how to play:
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Restrictions Lift, Countries Brace for a New Reality
description: As lockdowns begin to ease for millions of Europeans, Italy reports a spike in deaths. Migrants face roundups in Malaysia and surging infections in Singapore’s dormitories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Houston Helicopter Crash Kills 1 Police Officer and Injures Another
description: The officers were investigating a report of bodies in a bayou when the helicopter crashed near an apartment building, the authorities said.
content: A Houston police officer was killed and another critically injured after their helicopter crashed early Saturday morning as they were responding to a report of bodies in a bayou, the city’s police chief said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: She Predicted the Coronavirus. What Does She Foresee Next?
description: Laurie Garrett, the prophet of this pandemic, expects years of death and “collective rage.”
content: I told Laurie Garrett that she might as well change her name to Cassandra. Everyone is calling her that anyway.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French Muslims Face a Cruel Coronavirus Shortage: Burial Grounds
description: For many immigrant families, the pandemic has halted the tradition of repatriating bodies to their country of origin, and finding a plot in France has become ever more difficult.
content: PARIS — The middle-aged men, some wearing masks and gloves, leaned over a freshly excavated grave and gingerly slid a coffin into it. Arching their backs and bending their knees, they were burying a 60-year-old French-Moroccan woman in the Muslim section of a cemetery in a town north of Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Asadullah Timory
title: Afghanistan Investigating Claims Migrants Were Killed by Iranian Guards
description: About 50 Afghan migrants crossing into Iran illegally were beaten and thrown into a river, local news media and witnesses say. As many as half did not survive, they said.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The foreign ministry of Afghanistan on Saturday said it was investigating claims that dozens of Afghan migrants detained in Iran were tortured by that country’s border guards and thrown into a river, where many of them drowned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Tony Allen, Drummer Who Created the Beat of Afrobeat, Dies at 79
description: With the Nigerian bandleader Fela and later on his own, he merged West African styles with American jazz and funk, reaching listeners worldwide.
content: Tony Allen, the drummer who created the steadfast, subtle beat of the Nigerian protest funk known as Afrobeat, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Matt Phillips
title: Berkshire Hathaway Lost $49.7 Billion in First Quarter Stung by Coronavirus
description: The huge loss reflects the hit that the crisis has inflicted on Warren E. Buffett’s vast conglomerate.
content: Not even Warren E. Buffett was spared financially from the coronavirus, as his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, reported a $49.7 billion loss in the first quarter on Saturday, reflecting the outbreak’s toll on an investment portfolio that includes big stakes in major airlines and financial firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: With Over Two Dozen Deaths, London Bus Drivers Fear Coronavirus Risk
description: At least 28 bus drivers have died since the coronavirus outbreak began. And while new measures have been put in place to protect them, some worry it’s too little, too late.
content: London is a city gone quiet. Yet, with a stringent coronavirus lockdown in place and the normal bustle largely halted, bold red buses are still winding their way through the sprawling capital offering frequent service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley, Emily Flitter and David Enrich
title: Some Small Businesses That Got Aid Fear the Rules Too Much to Spend It
description: Requirements for using federal coronavirus loans are complicated and confusing for owners. “It’s chaos,” one lawyer said.
content: When a $192,000 loan from the federal government’s small-business aid program arrived in his bank account last month, George Evageliou, the founder of a custom woodworking company, felt like one of the lucky ones.
source.name: The New York Times
